Thanks for your pull request.  It looks like this may be your first contribution to a Google open source project. Before we can look at your pull request, you'll need to sign a Contributor License Agreement (CLA).

:memo: **Please visit <https://cla.developers.google.com/> to sign.**

Once you've signed, please reply here (e.g. `I signed it!`) and we'll verify.  Thanks.

---

- If you've already signed a CLA, it's possible we don't have your GitHub username or you're using a different email address.  Check [your existing CLA data](https://cla.developers.google.com/clas) and verify that your [email is set on your git commits](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).
- If you signed the CLA as a corporation, please let us know the company's name.

Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
What exactly are you trying to achieve by with this PR?
Decouple the C# code generator from protobufs as far as I can understand, and then get help on the parts that I don't yet.

Ok, you are trying to do some changes to the codegen. What is the reason why you are trying to that (why is decoupling important? what do you exactly mean by decoupling here?).
Also, please only open a pull request once you have some work ready to be reviewed and merged into grpc/grpc.

I am going to close this PR for now, feel free to reopen once you have something to review and provide a more detailed description.

The end goal would be to support flatbuffers in the same way that Go and C++ do.
See https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/issues/4314
Decoupling would mean that csharp_generator would only reference the grpc interface type in https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/compiler/schema_interface.h instead of relying on protobuf methods for things as trivial as printing.
This would make it easier to support other serialization methods.
Most of the work so far has been done rather blindly, as I've been unable to get anything to build properly; ares_build https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/10403 this, libprotoc.lib that, and stdbool.h the other.

Is there a preferred development environment?

I'm not convinced this is the best way to support flatbuffers codegen (wouldn't it be easier to just write a separate codegen for flatbuffers?), but seeing that it has been done for other languages, it should be doable (see https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/8063/files for python). I don't have any specific guidance though, besides looking on how it's been done for other languages.
I am generally in support of doing things a better way.  What do you have in mind?

A simpler way would be to just have two completely separate code generators - one for protocol buffers and one for flatbuffers. That would sacrifice some code reuse (but the generator is rather small), but the separation would be better and the flatbuffers plugin could be supported as part of grpc-ecosystem (we're moving the grift support there), rather than being part of grpc repository itself (where it doesn't really belong).
Btw, code generators for other serialization formats are not necessarily written in C++, so the reuse of such refactoring seems to be limited.
So would it be a good idea then to move the proto plugins to their own repo as well?

Not really. Even though gRPC is fully serialization format independent (and we are being careful in not bringing in the protobuf dependency where not necessary), we expect majority of users to use protobuf. So proving a bit of extra support (better integration, better docs) to for those who use protobuf seems reasonable.

@jtattermusch We are sharing the C++ gRPC codegen between Protobuf and FlatBuffers, and similar work has been done for Go, and an in-progress Python PR. I'm not sure why C# should be any different, and we'd rather not be duplicating the code generation effort. The C# port can use the work that's already been done for C++, and is not that invasive.

@gwvo   if this is part of a bigger effort that's been approved previously, I'm not against it. Do you have a document that summarizes the idea of how codegen code can be shared  (Ideally, you'd have gRFC proposal for this in grpc/grpc-proposal repo)? Also, can you link to work done for other languages?
I think the primary issue of this PR is that it doesn't really explain the context of the change (and I'm being forced to slowly dig out info about what should have been included in the PR description from the very beginning).

@jtattermusch I've never proposed anything, I simply made a PR that was accepted. See below how codegen is shared:

First gRPC PR (by me) that refactored the codegen to not have a hardcoded dependency on protobuf: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/6130
Commit that uses the above to add the gRPC codegen to FlatBuffers as-is: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/commit/48f37f9e0a04f2b60046dda7fef20a8b0ebc1a70
Similar work as was done for C++ done for Python: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/8063
Go support: https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/pull/4082
@aardappel I can review the change once it is not "work in progress" but something we could actually merge. I don't have cycles to help out more with the actual implementation unfortunately.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
